More than a quarter of general practice nursing staff across the UK are considering leaving their role within the next 12 months, a survey has indicated. Concerns over pay and feeling ‘undervalued’ were to blame for general practice nurses (GPNs) and other nursing staff wanting to walk away from the sector, according to the survey
The post GPs could see exodus of practice nursing staff, warns survey appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs could see exodus of practice nursing staff, warns survey

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
Exclusive GPs in one area could be forced to spend up to £20,000 a year on sending text messages to their patients, after the local ICB decided to put a limit on the number of texts it will fund. North East London ICB informed GPs of its intention to only fund seven ‘message fragments’ (approximately
The post GPs could have to pay £20k annually for text messaging amid ICB cost-saving measures appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs could have to pay £20k annually for text messaging amid ICB cost-saving measures

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
The amount of funding made available to pay GPs employed under the ARRS is ‘derisory’ and ‘uncompetitive’, the BMA has warned. The maximum reimbursement PCNs can claim for GPs in the Additional Roles Reimbursement Scheme (ARRS), who could be employed from 1 October, is £92,462 across England, except for those hired in London where it
The post Funding for GPs in ARRS ‘derisory’ and ‘uncompetitive’, BMA warns appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Funding for GPs in ARRS ‘derisory’ and ‘uncompetitive’, BMA warns

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
A number of childhood vaccines were stolen from a GP practice in County Durham over the weekend.  Cleveland Police are investigating a break-in at the Riverside Medical Practice in Stockton and have issued a warning to the public ‘about buying and using these products’. The police force is appealing for information about ‘two unknown men’
The post Childhood vaccines ‘worth £10-15k’ stolen in GP practice break-in appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Childhood vaccines ‘worth £10-15k’ stolen in GP practice break-in

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Dr Seema Pattni looks at imposter syndrome in general practice, and provides tips on what steps affected GPs can take to tackle it ‘Is my success truly my own?’ The GP asking me this is intelligent and hard-working. They have a good job, a stable family set-up and financial security. To the external gaze, they
The post Imposter syndrome in general practice appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Imposter syndrome in general practice

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Health secretary Wes Streeting has committed to a ‘refreshed’ NHS workforce plan next summer which will have a ‘laser-focus’ on boosting GP numbers. Over the weekend, Mr Streeting announced plans to rework the current NHS workforce strategy, published in 2023, which aims to increase GP training places by 50% to 6,000 by 2031. The Department
The post Government to update NHS workforce plan with focus on GP expansion appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Government to update NHS workforce plan with focus on GP expansion

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
Dapagliflozin and empagliflozin cut mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction whether or not patients have diabetes, a large real-world study has concluded. The analysis of sodium glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor drugs in patients on a national Danish registry found they were associated with a 25% lower risk of all-cause mortality,
The post SGLT-2 inhibitors benefit heart failure regardless of diabetes, finds real-world study appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: SGLT-2 inhibitors benefit heart failure regardless of diabetes, finds real-world study

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
Removing urgent care from GP practices as part of plans for neighbourhood health centres could ‘disrupt relationships’ with patients and lead to worse outcomes, the RCGP has warned. In its submission to a consultation on the NHS 10-year plan, the college said that the Government must define a ‘clear’ national vision for its plans of
The post Removing urgent care from GPs could ‘disrupt relationship’ with patients, RCGP warns appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Removing urgent care from GPs could ‘disrupt relationship’ with patients, RCGP warns

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Dr Helen Thomas explains the need for a public health campaign to tackle smartphone and social media use in children and young people Frontline GPs are well versed in public health education and the changing needs of our population. From the 1970s doctors have campaigned for changes in tobacco use. In the 80s, HIV/AIDS campaigns
The post The kids aren’t alright – GPs must lead debate on social media ban appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: The kids aren’t alright – GPs must lead debate on social media ban

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
GPs are still calling the police to attend mental health crises including suicidal ideation cases, despite an initiative trying to prevent this, a Government analysis has found. Police forces in England have stopped attending mental health callouts where there is no immediate risk to life or a crime is being committed, as part of the
The post GPs criticised for continuing to call police to attend mental health crises appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs criticised for continuing to call police to attend mental health crises

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The Government will not put in place interim safety measures regarding physician associates (PAs) ahead of the independent review into their safety, a health minister has said. Yesterday, the House of Lords held a debate on the upcoming PA review, with the Green Party’s Baroness Bennett calling on the Government to take ‘interim action’ to
The post Government will not commit to ‘interim action’ ahead of PA safety review appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Government will not commit to ‘interim action’ ahead of PA safety review

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
MPs from opposition parties have urged the Government to ‘rethink’ the Autumn Budget tax hikes due to concerns that these will threaten the viability of thousands of GP practices. The ‘deeply damaging’ impact of the hikes was debated in the House of Commons this week as several Conservative and Liberal Democrat MPs pointed out that the
The post Opposition parties urge Government to ‘rethink’ NIC rise for GP practices appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Opposition parties urge Government to ‘rethink’ NIC rise for GP practices

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
GP practice managers, PCN managers and PCN clinical directors could be regulated in similar ways to healthcare professionals under the Government’s new plans for NHS managers. The roles are under consideration to come under the scope of the proposals launched by the Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC) last week. Its public consultation sets out measures
The post GP practice managers and PCN directors could become subject to new regulation appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP practice managers and PCN directors could become subject to new regulation

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The GMC will make only minor tweaks to how it regulates physician associates (PAs) from next week, the long-awaited response to its technical consultation has outlined. Published today, the response to the consultation launched in March set out the small amendments while also trying to allay wider concerns raised by respondents. Speaking last month at
The post GMC to make only minor tweaks to PA regulation following lengthy consultation appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GMC to make only minor tweaks to PA regulation following lengthy consultation

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Forvis Mazars associate tax director Neelum Ali shares tips on how to throw a tax efficient Christmas, while still spreading the festive cheer Practices will still be reeling from the recent Budget announcements, which will place further stress on practice finances from April next year. There will be a great deal of planning required to
The post Finance diary: How to provide a tax efficient Christmas for your practice appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Finance diary: How to provide a tax efficient Christmas for your practice

articles.author: Caroline Price
articles.description:
Continuing our series on diagnoses that may be missed in a primary care setting, Dr Ahmed Mostafa describes a case of upper limb DVT that was initially misdiagnosed Note details of cases in this series have been altered to protect individuals’ identities A 39-year-old female patient presented with ongoing right arm pain and swelling lasting
The post Under the radar: upper limb DVT appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Under the radar: upper limb DVT

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
A pharmacy-led sore throat treatment service in Wales has been found to result in fewer same-day antibiotic prescriptions than those given during GP consultations, according to a new study. The study, published in the Journal of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy, found that pharmacy-led sore throat treatment provides a safe, effective, and cost-efficient alternative to GP consultations. The research, carried
The post Study shows benefits of pharmacy sore throat service over GP consultation appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Study shows benefits of pharmacy sore throat service over GP consultation

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
NICE has accepted a request from NHS England to slow down the roll out of weight-loss drug tirzepatide, reserving eligibility for those with the highest clinical need at first. However its final draft guidance on use of the weekly injection, published today, still means around a quarter of a million people gaining access to the
The post NICE accepts slower rollout of tirzepatide but GP workload concerns remain appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: NICE accepts slower rollout of tirzepatide but GP workload concerns remain

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The General Practice Alert System (GPAS), aimed at mapping workload pressures, is being retired as it has not had the uptake nor impact GPs had hoped for. Devon LMC began the OPEL-style mapping of general practice pressures in its own county in 2020 and has been producing a national heatmap since 2022, in a bid
The post GPs stop system pressure alerts amid poor uptake and disappointing impact appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs stop system pressure alerts amid poor uptake and disappointing impact

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Copperfield on the announcement of a men’s health strategy To be honest, I could barely summon the energy to yawn at Streeting’s announcement of a first-ever men’s health strategy. Here we go, another opportunity to bang drums, disseminate misinformation and, above all, reinforce stereotypes. So I just scratched my fat arse, ordered more chips and
The post Wes makes ballsy attempt to distract us from NHS chaos appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Wes makes ballsy attempt to distract us from NHS chaos

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
GPs can now prescribe antivirals for patients with symptoms of flu, after surveillance data showed a rise in cases. A letter to the NHS from the chief medical offer said influenza activity was increasing across all levels of care and is expected to rise further in coming weeks. The most notable changes include a ‘significant
The post GPs given go-ahead to prescribe antivirals after uptick in cases of flu appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs given go-ahead to prescribe antivirals after uptick in cases of flu

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Locum GPs have told Pulse they are owed thousands of pounds from a GP-led company which runs nine practices across Wales.  GPs have raised serious concerns about the England-based company, eHarley Street, which is owned by two GP partners. Pulse has spoken to six locum GPs who between them were owed over £32,000, despite having
The post Locums owed thousands speak out against large GP company appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Locums owed thousands speak out against large GP company

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
The UK has secured five million doses of a vaccine that would be used if the H5 bird flu virus spreads to humans. The influenza A(H5N1) virus has been causing a ‘prolonged global outbreak’, primarily in birds, over the past few years, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) said today. While there is currently no
The post UK purchases 5m doses of bird flu vaccine in case of human spread appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: UK purchases 5m doses of bird flu vaccine in case of human spread

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
The Government’s upcoming 10-year plan must include a commitment to negotiate a new GP contract that ‘revitalises’ general practice, the BMA has demanded. The plan should also end ‘the scandal of doctor joblessness’ taking ‘particular steps’ to address unemployment among sessional and locum GPs, the union said in its response to a consultation launched earlier
The post NHS 10-year plan must commit to a new GP contract, BMA demands appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: NHS 10-year plan must commit to a new GP contract, BMA demands

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
GP locum Dr Edoardo Cervoni calls for a more rational approach to diagnostic testing in primary care The overuse of diagnostic tests in primary care, particularly those related to nutrients like folic acid, vitamin B12, and zinc, is well-documented in literature.1 The primary driver behind this trend often lies in a ‘better safe than sorry’
The post GPs do too many diagnostic tests – but we can take a more rational approach appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs do too many diagnostic tests – but we can take a more rational approach

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
GLP-1 receptor agonist medication could be effective in reducing alcohol use by targeting the brain’s reward centre, a new study has suggested. Researchers at the University of Nottingham analysed whether GLP-1 RAs, currently used to treat diabetes and obesity, could help people cut down the amount of alcohol they consume. The findings are published in eClinicalMedicine and
The post GLP-1 drugs could help people drink less alcohol, research suggests appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GLP-1 drugs could help people drink less alcohol, research suggests

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
A Court of Appeal has ruled in favour of a GP partner who was issued with contract termination notices for refusing to cooperate with the local PCN. Following a years-long dispute, a judgment passed down today found that the CCG ‘failed to give notice of a variation’ in the GP partner’s contract and was therefore
The post GP wins appeal against contract termination over PCN non-cooperation appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP wins appeal against contract termination over PCN non-cooperation

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
Adults who have irregular sleep patterns are 26% more likely to have a major cardiovascular event than those with a regular sleep-wake cycle, a new study shows. Going to bed and waking up at different times was found to be detrimental to cardiac health and ‘strongly associated’ with an increased risk of heart attacks and
The post Irregular sleep patterns could increase risk of heart attack and stroke appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Irregular sleep patterns could increase risk of heart attack and stroke

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
The World Health Organisation (WHO) has raised the alarm about soaring cases of tuberculosis (TB) around the world. Last year, more than eight million people were newly diagnosed with the condition, the highest number since they began monitoring in 1995, WHO said. While TB-related deaths did fall last year from 1.32 million to 1.25 million
The post WHO raises alarm about growing rates of tuberculosis globally appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: WHO raises alarm about growing rates of tuberculosis globally

articles.author: Mollie Fraser-Andrews
articles.description:
In our latest in the series, Dr Donagh McDonagh asks what could be wrong with this 43-year-old man with a rash and a groin lump. Suggest your answers below the line! A 43-year-old male contacted his GP surgery with a single groin lump and a skin rash. Practice staff had invited the patient to submit
The post Case of the month: What is wrong with this middle-aged man with pityriasis rosea? appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Case of the month: What is wrong with this middle-aged man with pityriasis rosea?

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The cost of NHS clinical negligence claims may come down following a decision from the Treasury to increase the personal injury discount rate (PIDR) from January.  Today, Lord Chancellor Shabana Mahmood has announced an increase in the PIDR from -0.25% to +0.5% in England and Wales, following a review of the rate which takes place
The post NHS clinical negligence costs likely to reduce after Treasury decision appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: NHS clinical negligence costs likely to reduce after Treasury decision

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
Dr Burnt Out takes issue with the BMA’s ‘assistance’ in preparing the Assisted Dying Bill. As I am sure a lot of you did, I watched with interest the events unfold regarding Kim Leadbeater’s bill on physician-assisted dying last Friday which passed, and for all intents and purposes set in motion a chain of events
The post Dr Burnt Out on assisted dying: The meaning of neutrality appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Dr Burnt Out on assisted dying: The meaning of neutrality

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The RCGP will consult members to establish a position on assisted dying following a new bill’s progress in Parliament.  Over the weekend, the RCGP council voted in favour of mandating the college to ‘undertake a new all-member survey’ to inform a future decision on its ‘principle stance on the legalisation of assisted dying’.  This meant
The post GPs will be consulted on assisted dying laws to establish RCGP position appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs will be consulted on assisted dying laws to establish RCGP position

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
A drug already used in the treatment of severe asthma could help treat exacerbations in asthma and COPD, a UK trial has found. Monoclonal antibody benralizamab was found to be more effective than a dose of steroids when patients had gone to urgent care clinics or emergency departments with acute symptoms and high eosinophil counts.
The post Existing asthma drug found to be ‘game-changer’ in asthma and COPD attacks appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Existing asthma drug found to be ‘game-changer’ in asthma and COPD attacks

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
The RCGP has called for a temporary pause of CQC routine inspections of GP practices due to concerns about the current regulation system. The college’s governing council also called for an end to ‘simplistic’ one-word ratings currently used in CQC inspections, during a meeting on Saturday (30 November). The proposed pause would only be for
The post RCGP calls for pause to routine CQC inspections appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: RCGP calls for pause to routine CQC inspections

articles.description: GP leaders say an £889m funding uplift in 2025/26 could be 'an important lifeline' that avoids redundancies and contract hand-backs in general practice - but warned that detail on how the money works will be key, and that a 'long road' lies ahead.
articles.title: Is £889m the lifeline practices need to keep them afloat?

articles.description: Rising numbers of doctors are seeking support after experiencing domestic abuse, but cases are often under-reported by clinicians for fear of professional repercussions, a doctors’ charity has said.
articles.title: Rise in doctors reporting domestic abuse, charity reveals

articles.description: Writing for GPonline as the government unveiled an £889m general practice funding boost, primary care minister Stephen Kinnock says next year's contract will ease financial pressure on practices, strip away red tape and 'bring back the family doctor'.
articles.title: Stephen Kinnock: New contract can liberate GPs to build a neighbourhood NHS

articles.description: The government will increase overall funding for general practice by £889m in 2025/26 in what it says is the 'biggest boost to GP funding in years'.
articles.title: Government unveils £889m GP funding boost for 2025/26

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to Charlotte Osborn Forde and Dr Radha Modgil from the National Academy for Social Prescribing about the evidence that supports the use of social prescribing and how general practice - and the rest of the NHS - can get the best from social prescribing.
articles.title: Podcast: How the NHS can get the best from social prescribing

articles.description: GP consultations for flu-like illness rose by 42% in the week to 15 December, reflecting a spike in workload in general practice as NHS leaders warned that hospitals had been 'flooded' with cases in an early surge of illness before Christmas.
articles.title: Winter pressure surge for GPs as flu consultations pass epidemic threshold

articles.description: A former practice manager has been ordered to pay back £44,000 after stealing more than £300,000 from the surgery she once worked for, leaving it facing 'substantial financial risk', staff fearing for their jobs and one GP partner experiencing panic attacks.
articles.title: Practice manager to pay back £44,000 after theft left GP facing panic attacks

articles.description: Salaried GPs are on the increase in every part of England and partners are in decline almost everywhere. But the rate of change is hugely varied across England - GPonline looks at how the balance is changing in the GP workforce and where that shift is happening fastest.
articles.title: Where is the balance between partners and salaried GPs changing fastest?

articles.description: It is 'rational' for GPs to see the Pharmacy First scheme as a financial threat after years of underfunding - and competition between the two sectors needs to be addressed, the health and social care secretary has told MPs.
articles.title: Government to tackle financial tension between GPs and pharmacies

articles.description: Health and social care secretary Wes Streeting has suggested GP practices could find out in January where they stand on employer national insurance - but refused to guarantee the costs would be covered in full, in evidence to MPs.
articles.title: Streeting refuses to promise GP NI support but hints at January update

articles.description: GPs in Wales have voted overwhelmingly to reject the government's 2024/25 GMS contract offer - with 99% voting against the deal.
articles.title: GPs in Wales vote to reject 2024/25 contract offer

articles.description: Labour MP and GP Dr Simon Opher is one of 23 MPs who will sit on the assisted dying bill committee that will scrutinise the proposed legislation before it is next voted on in palrliament.
articles.title: GP MP to sit on assisted dying legislation committee

articles.description: Patients per GP have risen slightly across England over the past two years as the population grew faster than the GP workforce - but one in three ICBs have moved the dial in the other direction. Find out how your area compares with the chart and table below.
articles.title: How have patients per GP in your area changed in the past two years?

articles.description: The Liberal Democrats have launched a bid to exempt GP practices from a 'self-defeating' rise in employer national insurance announced in the autumn budget after fears it could force practice closures and reduce GP appointments.
articles.title: Lib Dem bid to exempt GPs from 'self-defeating' NI hike

articles.description: GPs' wellbeing could be put at risk if they receive fitness to practise (FTP) allegations just before Christmas - a time when mental health risks can increase for some people, medico-legal experts have warned.
articles.title: GPs' wellbeing at risk from FTP allegations at Christmas, warns MDU

articles.description: Salaried GPs should receive a 20% pay increase on top of inflation next year according to BMA evidence to the Doctors and Dentists Review Body (DDRB) that also calls for a new approach to advice on overall contract uplifts.
articles.title: BMA urges DDRB to rethink contract uplifts and back 20% pay rise for salaried GPs

articles.description: The GMC has begun writing to physician associates (PAs) and anaesthesia associates (AAs) from today to invite them to join its professional register in a landmark moment for healthcare regulation.
articles.title: Landmark moment as GMC invites first physician associates to join register

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses the key news stories affecting general practice, including the challenges facing the NHS this winter, how the GP jobs crisis is affecting locums and whether GPs in Wales and Scotland could take industrial action.
articles.title: Podcast: Winter pressures, falling locum pay, how one area transformed its patient per GP ratio

articles.description: A £3-a-month increase in general practice funding per patient could bring an extra 3,500 full-time GPs into the workforce overnight, an organisation representing doctors has estimated.
articles.title: Around 3,500 GPs could be hired overnight for £35 per patient

articles.description: A £3-a-month increase in general practice funding per patient could bring an extra 3,500 full-time GPs into the workforce overnight, an organisation representing doctors has estimated.
articles.title: Around 3,500 out-of-work GPs could be hired overnight for £35 per patient

articles.description: The GMC has become the official regulator of physician associates (PAs) and anaesthesia associates (AAs) from today despite ongoing concerns from doctors over the move.
articles.title: GMC regulation of physician associates begins despite doctors' concerns

articles.description: GPs need a new contract that brings an end to competing incentives with pharmacy and allows them the financial freedom to build services around patients, policy experts have said.
articles.title: GP and pharmacy contracts need 'harmonising' to end competing incentives, MPs told

articles.description: GP practices in Cheshire and Merseyside have lost out on nearly £4m in funding after the ICB slashed a ‘ringfenced’ primary care transformation fund - just months after NHS England admitted budgets were being raided to cover hospital deficits.
articles.title: ICB cuts deny GPs millions of pounds 'ringfenced' for general practice

articles.description: GP practices serving England's most deprived areas receive almost 10% less funding per patient than their counterparts in the most affluent areas, according to a report that calls for the 'outdated and unfair' Carr-Hill formula to be scrapped.
articles.title: Outdated GP funding formula leaves practices in deprived areas with 10% less funding

articles.description: Government evidence to the doctors and dentists pay review body (DDRB) backs a 2.8% pay increase for GPs and other doctors in 2025/26 - a rise the BMA warned shows a 'poor grasp' of factors that led to industrial action.
articles.title: Government backs 2.8% GP pay increase for 2025/26

articles.description: GP practices have been on the receiving end of ‘threats’ and ‘intimidating behaviour’ from patients who are unhappy with the impact of collective action, an LMC has revealed.
articles.title: GP practice staff 'threatened' by patients over collective action, reveals LMC

articles.description: A GP registrar has launched a research project into the impact of 'hidden workload' in general practice - warning that general practice staff face 'constant firefighting' against tasks that consume hours of their time but are not part of their official daily schedules.
articles.title: Doctor lifts lid on ‘constant firefighting’ against hidden general practice work

articles.description: The government has promised more GPs as part of a revamped NHS workforce plan it will publish next summer - replacing an existing plan criticised for being built on 'substitution' of GPs with other healthcare staff.
articles.title: Government promises more GPs in revamped NHS workforce plan

articles.description: A GP practice in Yorkshire has warned it will be forced to hand back its contract within weeks unless a solution to increased employer national insurance (NI) contributions is announced - sparking fears of a 'domino effect' of practice closures.
articles.title: GPs fear 'domino effect' as practice set to close over NI hike

articles.description: Next spring, the government has promised to publish a 10-year plan setting out the 'biggest reimagining of the NHS' in its 76-year history. GPonline looks at what the BMA and RCGP say the plan should deliver for general practice.
articles.title: What do GPs want from the 10-year NHS plan?

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to GP Dr Jonathan Griffiths, associate medical director for primary care at NHS Cheshire and Merseyside ICB, about the work he's been doing in his area to address problems that occur at the interface between primary and secondary care.
articles.title: Podcast: How can we solve problems at the primary/secondary care interface?

articles.description: The GMC has set out changes to its plans for regulation of physician associates (PAs) and anaesthesia associates (AAs) after most respondents to a major consultation disagreed with broad swathes of its proposals.
articles.title: GMC revises physician associate regulation plans after negative consultation findings

articles.description: The NHS is 'busier than ever before' heading into winter and could face an emerging 'quad-demic' as numbers of patients hospitalised with flu, norovirus, COVID-19 and RSV surge, the health service's medical director has warned.
articles.title: NHS 'quad-demic' fears as flu and norovirus cases surge

articles.description: GP registrars are increasingly turning their backs on partnership roles, with growing numbers also considering working abroad, in private healthcare or outside medicine, an alarming survey reveals.
articles.title: GP registrars rejecting partnership and considering work overseas, survey shows

articles.description: GP leaders have urged caution over the rollout of obesity drug tirzepatide after final draft guidance from NICE set out plans to offer it to almost quarter of a million people over the next three years.
articles.title: Warning over impact on GPs as NICE announces three-year tirzepatide rollout

articles.description: A GP partner served with contract termination notices after refusing to co-operate with a PCN has won a legal appeal with significant implications for general practice.
articles.title: Court victory for GP who refused to join PCN opens new legal window for practices

articles.description: Over the past two years, the number of patients registered with GP practices across England has risen roughly twice as fast as the fully-qualified GP workforce - leaving general practice stretched thinner and thinner. But some areas have bucked the trend - and one area in particular has moved the dial in a remarkable way.
articles.title: How part of England bucked the national trend and grew its GP workforce

articles.description: GP leaders have called for the CQC to pause routine inspections and scrap one-word ratings in recommendations sent to the government.
articles.title: CQC should pause routine inspections and scrap one-word ratings, says RCGP

articles.description: More than half of GPs think existing physician associate (PA) roles in general practice should be phased out, according to a GPonline poll.
articles.title: Most GPs believe PA roles in general practice should be phased out

articles.description: GMC regulation of physician associates (PAs) will begin from next week - and critics of the plans should recognise 'that ship has sailed', the regulator's chief executive has said.
articles.title: No turning back on GMC regulation of physician associates, says chief executive

articles.description: Newly-qualified GPs are still struggling to find work and considering careers abroad despite plans to create more than 1,000 jobs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS), GP trainers have warned.
articles.title: ARRS jobs have not solved employment crisis for newly-qualified GPs, trainers warn

articles.description: The RCGP has said it will consult members on what its position should be on legalising assisted dying, as it insisted any change in the law must ensure there are clear protections to allow GPs to opt out of the process.
articles.title: RCGP to consult members over its stance on assisted dying

articles.description: The RCGP has said it will consult members on what its position should be on legalising assisted dying, as it insisted any change in the law must ensure there are clear protections to allow GPs to opt out of the process.
articles.title: RCGP to consult members on its assisted dying position

articles.description: The shortage of GP jobs has driven down locum rates by around 2% in the past six months and pushed more doctors into private sector roles, a sessional GP organisation has warned.
articles.title: GP job shortage forces locums to cut fees and take on private work

sources.title: Public Health England - Activity on GOV.UK

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: Around one hundred people a month in England have avoided a stroke over the last year thanks to a lifesaving NHS rollout of blood thinning medication. Over the last year, one million people with Atrial Fibrillation (AF) – a condition that causes an irregular and often abnormally fast heartbeat – have been prescribed anticoagulant medication […]
articles.title: NHS prevents thousands of strokes, thanks to lifesaving drive

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: The NHS in England is facing an “uphill battle” with demand for gambling addiction help more than doubling since last year.  Referrals have gone up almost 130%, with almost 2,000 people referred to gambling clinics between April and September this year, compared to just over 800 in the same period last year. However to manage […]
articles.title: NHS Tackles Problem Gambling Amid Growing Demand

articles.author: fraja
articles.description: The NHS in England is facing an “uphill battle” with demand for gambling addiction help more than doubling since last year. Referrals have gone up almost 130%, with almost 2,000 people referred to gambling clinics between April and September this year, compared to just over 800 in the same period last year. However to manage […]
articles.title: NHS Tackles Problem Gambling Amid Growing Demand

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: Booze, burns and bites are top of the list of NHS health advice being sought over Christmas. The NHS website’s information on alcohol, burns, rabies and animal bites showed the biggest increases in visits on Christmas Day and Boxing Day last year, newly released figures from NHS England show. Top of the list was advice […]
articles.title: Booze, burns and bites top NHS Christmas health advice list

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: The head of the NHS in England has praised staff for “working tirelessly” and “constantly innovating” to modernise care for patients in her Christmas message to health workers. Amanda Pritchard, Chief Executive of NHS England, spoke about how NHS innovations are improving care and providing better value for money during a visit to Sutton Health […]
articles.title: NHS chief focuses on innovation and staff commitment in Christmas message

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: As family and friends gather for the festive period, the NHS is highlighting the signs and symptoms of dementia to look out for in loved ones. Common early symptoms of dementia that may appear some time before an official medical diagnosis include: emotional changes such as irritability forgetfulness struggling to follow a conversation or find […]
articles.title: NHS highlights dementia symptoms to look out for over Christmas as numbers diagnosed soar

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: England’s top doctor is warning the public about the risk of ‘bargain-basement’ Brazilian Butt lifts, following a stream of deals being offered by overseas clinics in the run up to Christmas.  The NHS has seen clinics offering 25% discounts, all-inclusive packages including hotels and flights for under £3,000, as well as finance deals in a […]
articles.title: NHS warns of ‘bargain basement’ BBLs in run up to Christmas

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: The NHS is encouraging people to gift their loved ones the NHS App this Christmas, so they can order prescriptions, manage appointments and check test results over the festive period. As the health service combats its busiest ever start to winter, the NHS wants to ensure that patients have easy access to care, amid a […]
articles.title: NHS chief urges public to “unwrap the NHS App” this Christmas

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: Flu cases in hospital have already surpassed last year’s peak as festive infections “flood” hospitals early this winter. Latest weekly figures published today show one in 18 hospital beds are being taken up or closed by a festive bug, with 2,504 beds alone being taken up by flu patients – an increase of almost half on […]
articles.title: Winter pressure builds as no sign of ‘festive flu’ letting up

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: Hundreds of thousands of older and frail patients will receive urgent treatment from home this winter, as part of NHS plans to manage additional pressure this winter. Rapid teams based in local neighbourhoods will attend less clinically urgent calls within two hours and treat patients for a range of conditions and issues at home. From […]
articles.title: Hundreds of thousands of older people to get urgent care at home this winter

articles.author: rwootton
articles.description: The roll-out of Martha’s Rule in NHS hospitals in England has already begun triggering “potentially life-saving changes in care” for patients, Martha Mills’ parents and the NHS have today announced. The major patient safety initiative aims to provide a consistent and understandable way for patients and families to seek an urgent review if their or […]
articles.title: Martha’s Rule ‘already saving lives’ in NHS hospitals

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: The NHS is urging those eligible for vaccination to come forward without delay before the National Booking Service closes this Thursday (19 December). Latest data shows over half a million vaccinations for flu and COVID-19 have now been booked in the last five weeks alone, with the NHS today making a “last chance saloon” call […]
articles.title: Final chance to book jabs to avoid ‘festive flu’

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: Thousands more people in England booked their winter vaccines yesterday (Thursday) after the NHS warned of a “tidal wave” of flu and other seasonal viruses hitting hospitals.  The number of flu and COVID-19 jab appointments booked through the NHS’s national booking system more than doubled from 9,452 on Wednesday to 21,144 on Thursday – a […]
articles.title: NHS winter vaccine bookings surge following flu ‘tidal wave’ warning

articles.author: rwootton
articles.description: Flu hit hospitals in England even harder last week, as a ‘tidal wave’ of infections led to a 70% increase in hospital cases across just 7 days. The NHS is encouraging eligible people to get vaccinated without delay if they haven’t done so already to avoid “festive flu” with an average of 1,861 patients with […]
articles.title: ‘Tidal wave’ of flu hitting hospitals amid record treatment delivered for patients

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: The NHS is using AI to predict patients who are at risk of becoming frequent users of emergency services so staff can get them more appropriate care at an earlier stage. The intervention will ensure that thousands of people get the support they need earlier, while also reducing demand on pressured A&Es. Over 360,000 patients […]
articles.title: NHS artificial intelligence (AI) giving patients better care and support

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: The NHS is offering flu jabs to people at football clubs, supermarkets and Christmas markets as it braces itself for a rise in winter viruses in the coming weeks. articles.title: Don’t spend your Christmas holidays in bed with the flu

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: Today, NHS England has published the results from the new National Diabetes Experience Survey. Dr Clare Hambling, National Clinical Director of Diabetes and Obesity at NHS England said: “The NHS is committed to offering effective support, treatment and care to people living with diabetes, and this survey shows our range of innovative services is helping thousands […]
articles.title: NHS publishes landmark survey into diabetes

articles.author: rwootton
articles.description: The NHS is urging people to come forward for their flu vaccination without delay so they and their families are protected in time for Christmas. UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) data shows flu cases are highest among those aged 5 to 14, and the NHS is urging those eligible for a flu jab to make […]
articles.title: “Now or never” for people to protect themselves in time for Christmas

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: The effectiveness of health measures in getting people back into work or keeping them in work will be trialled by the NHS in the coming months. Backed by £45 million from the autumn Budget and supported by the government, the world leading trial will see the NHS create ‘Health and Growth Accelerators’ in South Yorkshire, […]
articles.title: World leading NHS trial to boost health and support people in work

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: NHS fears of a potential ‘quad-demic’ are rising with a 350% increase in flu cases and an 86% rise in norovirus cases in hospital compared to same week last year – alongside concerns about rising COVID-19 and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)c levels in hospitals. New weekly figures published today for the first time this year, […]
articles.title: Hospitals managing record flu levels going into Winter

articles.author: rwootton
articles.description: The first ever drug for an aggressive form of eye cancer is being fast-tracked to hundreds of patients by the NHS across England. One patient receiving the treatment described the rollout as “the best early Christmas present I could’ve asked for”. Patients diagnosed with uveal melanoma, which once it has spread to major organs is […]

articles.description:
WHO is appalled by yesterday’s raid on Kamal Adwan Hospital, which put the last major health facility in North Gaza out of service. The systematic dismantling of the health system and a siege for over 80 days on North Gaza puts the lives of the 75,000 Palestinians remaining in the area at risk.

Initial reports indicate that some areas of the hospital were burnt and severely damaged during the raid, including the laboratory, surgical unit, engineering and maintenance department, operations theatre, and the medical store. Earlier in the day, twelve patients and a female health staff were reportedly forced to evacuate to destroyed and non-functional Indonesian Hospital where it is not possible to provide any care, while the majority of the staff, stable patients and companions were moved to …
articles.title: Kamal Adwan Hospital out of service following a raid yesterday and repeated attacks since October

articles.description:
Our mission to negotiate the release of the United Nations staff detainees and to assess the health and humanitarian situation in Yemen concluded today. 
We continue to call for the detainees' immediate release.  
As we were about to board our flight from Sana’a, about three hours ago (around 5 pm local time), the airport came under aerial bombardment.  One of our plane’s crew members was injured.  At least two people were reported killed at the airport.  
The air traffic control tower, the departure lounge — just a few meters from where we were — and the runway were damaged.  We will need to wait for the damage to the airport to be repaired before we can leave. 
My UN and WHO colleagues and I are safe. 
Our heartfelt condolences to the families whose loved ones lost their lives in the attack.
articles.title: Statement by Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General on the attack on the Sana'a airport, Yemen

articles.description: A Strategic Partnership Framework (SPF) with the Ministry of Development Cooperation and Humanitarian Affairs and multiyear agreement with the Ministry of Health and Social Safety was signed on 20 December 2024. By signing two new partnership agreements, Luxembourg reaffirmed its continued support for WHO to fulfill a shared mission to promote, provide and protect health.
articles.title: Luxembourg and WHO sign two strategic agreements

articles.description:
Key points: 


Vaccination remains an important public health countermeasure against COVID-19. As per the WHO Director General’s  standing recommendations for COVID-19, Member States are recommended to continue to offer COVID-19 vaccination based on the recommendations of the  WHO Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization (SAGE).
SARS-CoV-2 continues to circulate and evolve with important genetic and antigenic evolution of the spike protein since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic.
The objective of an update to COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition is to enhance vaccine-induced immune responses to circulating SARS-CoV-2 variants.
The WHO TAG-CO-VAC advises retaining the use of a monovalent JN.1 lineage variant as the antigen in future formulations of COVID-19 vaccines.
In acco…
articles.title: Statement on the antigen composition of COVID-19 vaccines

articles.description:
A new report, entitled “Relationality in community engagement: its role in humanizing healthcare and achieving quality integrated health Services” has been developed in collaboration with the Qatar Foundation for Education, Science and Community Development (QF) and launched at the Seventh edition of the World Innovation Summit for Health (WISH) taking place in Doha on 13–14 November 2024.
In the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, community engagement has further resurfaced as a necessary condition, and a shared responsibility within health systems, for emergency preparedness, response and recovery efforts in global public health. 
The new report introduces the background and current policy context for community engagement across different WHO regions. It presents an Integrated Change Fra…
articles.title: Relationality in community engagement: its role in humanizing health and achieving quality integrated health services

articles.description:
The ceasefire and the cessation of hostilities took effect on 27 November, offering temporary relief for the millions of civilians caught in the conflict in Lebanon. But Lebanon’s suffering did not end amid staggering unmet health needs. Bordering Syria and Israel, Lebanon’s overburdened health system is reeling from the impacts of an economic crisis, political deadlock, refugee crisis and now war. 
The country is host to 1.5 million Syrian refugees: inevitably, events in Syria impact Lebanon and WHO operations. Syrian nationals are entering Lebanon at the same time as Syrian refugees are returning to Syria from Lebanon.
"An already decimated health system remarkably withstood this latest storm, but it has been further weakened. The challenges are complex and call for specialized, sustaine…
articles.title: Lebanon: soaring needs for trauma treatment and rehabilitation

articles.description: The WHO Academy in Lyon, France, officially opened its doors today with a high-profile inauguration ceremony. The Academy aims to tackle the growing global shortage of health and care workers, projected to reach 10 million by 2030, by training thousands of health professionals each year.
articles.title: President Macron, WHO Director-General, and global health leaders inaugurate WHO Academy in Lyon

articles.description:
The 2024 Global Heath Expenditure Report by the World Health Organization (WHO) shows that the average per capita government spending on health in all country income groups fell in 2022 from 2021 after a surge in the early pandemic years. The report entitled, “Global spending on health Emerging from the pandemic” has been published in alignment with the  Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Day campaign marked annually on 12 December. The campaign’s focus for 2024 is on improving financial protection for people everywhere to access health services they need.
Government spending on health is crucial to delivering UHC. Its deprioritization can have dire consequences in a context where 4.5 billion people worldwide lack access to basic health services and 2 billion people face financial hardship du…
articles.title: New WHO report reveals governments deprioritizing health spending

articles.description:
Around 846 million people aged between 15 and 49 are living with genital herpes infections – more than 1 in 5 of this age-group globally – according to new estimates released today. At least 1 person each second – 42 million people annually – is estimated to acquire a new genital herpes infection.
Most of the time, these infections cause no or few symptoms. However, for some people they lead to painful genital sores and blisters that can recur throughout life, causing significant discomfort and often requiring multiple healthcare visits. According to the estimates, more than 200 million people aged 15 to 49 suffered at least one such symptomatic episode in 2020. 
The authors of the study, published in the journal Sexually Transmitted Infections, say that new treatments and vaccines are nee…
articles.title: Over 1 in 5 adults worldwide has a genital herpes infection – WHO

articles.description: New data from the World Health Organization (WHO) reveal that an estimated 2.2 billion cases of malaria and 12.7 million deaths have been averted since 2000, but the disease remains a serious global health threat, particularly in the WHO African Region.
articles.title: Reinvigorated global efforts needed to curb rising malaria threat

articles.description: WHO publishes its first-ever report on drowning prevention, which reveals a 38% drop in the global drowning death rate since 2000—a major global health achievement. However, the report notes that drowning remains a major public health issue.
articles.title: Drowning deaths decline globally but the most vulnerable remain at risk

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) has granted prequalification to the molecular diagnostic test for tuberculosis (TB) called Xpert® MTB/RIF Ultra. It is the first test for TB diagnosis and antibiotic susceptibility testing that meets WHO's prequalification standards. 
Tuberculosis is one of the world’s leading infectious disease killers, causing over a million deaths annually and imposing immense socioeconomic burdens, especially in low- and middle-income countries. Accurate and early detection of TB, especially drug-resistant strains, remains a critical and challenging global health priority. 
“This first prequalification of a diagnostic test for tuberculosis marks a critical milestone in WHO’s efforts to support countries in scaling up and accelerating access to high-quality TB assays …
articles.title: WHO announces first prequalification of a tuberculosis diagnostic test
